head.citation-title: Quaternion weighted spherical Bessel-Fourier moment and its invariant for color image reconstruction and object recognition
head.abstracts: Â© 2019 Elsevier Inc.Moments with capable of representing global features have been widely used in image analysis, pattern recognition and computer vision applications. However, existing image moment theories are still mainly paid close attention to gray-scale images. In this paper, a new quaternion moment termed as Quaternion weighted Spherical Bessel–Fourier Moment (QSBFM) is proposed to address the issue of color image analysis. Moreover, the relationship between QSBFM and the conventional weighted spherical Bessel–Fourier moment has been established so that the computational cost of QSBFM can be efficiently reduced. Furthermore, the natively geometric invariance of QSBFM is presented and discussed in detail. Experimental results show that the proposed QSBFM outperforms frequently-used quaternion moments including quaternion Bessel–Fourier moment, quaternion Radial-Harmonic-Fourier moment, quaternion Chebyshev-Fourier moment and quaternion orthogonal Fourier–Mellin moment in terms of the color image reconstruction capability and invariant recognition accuracy in noise-free, Salt & Pepper noise and the Gaussian noise conditions.

classification.classification-description: Computer Theory (Includes Formal Logic, Automata Theory, Switching Theory and Programming Theory)

grant-text.$: This work was supported by the Key Program of NSFC Grant (Grant no. U1405255), Shaanxi Science & Technology Coordination & Innovation Project (Grant no. 2016KTZDGY05-06), the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (Grant nos. SA-ZD161504, and JB171504), the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant no. 61702404), the Project funded by China Postdoctoral Science Foundation (Grant n. 2017M613080). The authors would like to thank the editor and the anonymous reviewers for their constructive comments to further improve the quality of this paper.

coredata.dc:description: Moments with capable of representing global features have been widely used in image analysis, pattern recognition and computer vision applications. However, existing image moment theories are still mainly paid close attention to gray-scale images.
